This is British Cinema at it`s best, a rousing Northwest Frontier picture with all the right ingredients, lots of Ã¢â‚¬ËœgoodiesÃ¢â‚¬â„¢, a real Ã¢â‚¬ËœbaddieÃ¢â‚¬â„¢, and a dashing hero, with a fiesty female lead in the form of Lauren Bacall.
Things do pile up on the characters in the old train as it goes from place to place in an effort to save a young Prince, but things never go over the top, and the acting is first rate, as well as the direction.

The movie is beautifully filmed, with great vistas of wilderness and excellent colour. Train-spotters will enjoy the railway details.
This is highly recommended family viewing that Ã¢â‚¬â€œ like so many of those 50?s adventure tales - it is great fun !!!
Great actors, good script, fine views, bags of excitement, a villain in the party and moral messages. What more do we need from a movie?

Thundering through its action sequences like a runaway locomotive, North West Frontier finds little to say about British colonial rule in India. Just as well it throws up enough epic battle sequences and nail-biting thrills to make amends.

From a smash opening to quietly confident fade, North West Frontier is basically the ageless chase yarn, transferred from the prairie to the sun-baked plains of India and done with a spectacular flourish.

An excellent adventure film which turns the Raj into an apposite backdrop for the British equivalent of a Western.Kenneth More is a British officer who must aid the escape of a Hindu prince from a city besieged by the Muslims. This he does by means of a decrepit steam train, with a handful of Western passengers on board, one of them an enemy agent. It's exciting stuff, with reams of incident, confident dialogue, and impeccable 'Scope photography by Geoffrey Unsworth.
